siteMetadata.title: The Node-API Resource
siteMetadata.description: Tutorials and more for Node.js Node-API.
siteMetadata.keywords: node nodejs n-api napi tutorials native-addon

children.value: One of the limitations of implementing native add-on modules is that at some point they need to be compiled and linked. In the absence of a downloadable binary, each user of a native add-on will need to compile and link the module. This requires each user to have the necessary C/C++ build tools installed.
An alternative is for the native add-on maintainer to pre-build binaries for supported platforms and architectures and to upload these binaries to a location where users can download them.
This is the specific solution offered by
Note that Node-API support was added to prebuild in version 8.1.0.
is an alternative tool that addresses this same issue.
This page describes the modifications required to an Node-API add-on module in order for it to support prebuild.
The capabilities offered by prebuild are actually delivered by two separate packages:
— For the users of your native add-on.
As a developer, you will use
to build and upload your binaries. The users of your native add-on will use
to first attempt to download one of your pre-built binaries before falling back to building the binary themselves.
When getting started with prebuild, it’s easiest to install
As you become proficient in prebuild, you may choose to alternatively install
By default, prebuild uploads generated binaries as
. Creating and uploading GitHub releases requires the use of a GitHub personal access token. The steps to create a token are as follows:
Go to the Github page to create
if you will be uploading only to public repositories.
if you will be uploading to private repositories.
Make a note of the generated token as this will be the only time it is visible.
environment variable containing the token.  For example:

children.value: to request Node-API builds. When requesting Node-API builds, the module’s
property as described next. And the
arguments may be specified to request builds for specific Node-API versions. Node-API versions are positive integer values. Alternatively,
may be used to request builds for all Node-API versions supported by the module.
will build the most current version of the module supported by the Node instance performing the build.

properties.ariaLabel: the code classlanguage textbinarycode property permalink

children.value: Native modules that are designed to work with
must explicitly declare the Node-API version(s) against which they can build. This is accomplished by including a
In the absence of a need to compile against a specific Node-API version, the value
is a good choice as this is the Node-API version that was supported when Node-API left experimental status.
Modules that are built against a specific Node-API version will continue to operate indefinitely, even as later versions of Node-API are introduced.
The Node-API header files supplied with Node use the

preprocessor value supplied by the user to configure each build to the specific Node-API version for which the native addon is being built. In addition, the module’s C/C++ code can use this value to conditionally compile code based on the Node-API version it is being compiled against.
value is configured differently for each backend.
The following code must be included in the
The following line must be included in the

properties.ariaLabel: building and uploading your binary permalink

children.value: entries as a starting point, this command will build and package your native add-on:
You can run this command as often as necessary.
When you’re ready, run this command to upload your compiled binary to GitHub:
environment variable contains a valid GitHub token as described above.
Once you become proficient in prebuild, you can modify the
entries to meet your specific needs.
When a user installs your native add-on, the
tool first looks to see if it can locate a suitable pre-built binary on GitHub for the user’s specific Node-API version, architecture, and platform. If the binary is found,
downloads, unpacks, and installs the binaries in the correct location.
If the binary is not found, the
script falls back to whatever is specified after the
is triggered which will attempt to build the binary on the user’s machine.
